text:
hey question for you all. working on a site with memberships where we have two different sets of memberships. membership to pages "A" and membership to pages "B". We have lists running to control the audience and they do not match (they are entirely different lists for A and B).

However, when someone is signing in, they apparently now have access to both pages tied to A and B.

We created A awhile back and it worked well, but when now that we've created B, we're finding that people who never were added to A can access it.

Are we doing something wrong? or is this supposed to happen? Essentially it's like an idea of creating an LMS for a client where the users can purchase several different courses, but only have access to those they purchase. It will defeat the purpose if you can purchase one time and have access to everything haha.
<@U25AA7L3D> check your list criteria on the content for private content
haha. nevermind dude, I figured it out.
Happy to riff on it further.

<@UG52C29EE> I am unfamiliar with HubDB permissions, do you know?  Only contacts who have access will see the video urls on the webpage but they could theoretically share the URLs with other people who donâ€™t have accesss.

Yes, You need to set the hubdb table as `public` in the table settings so hubdb api calls can be made without any access tokens or auth. So you can call the APIs from any non-protected pages via ajax..
